body: ### [! The Last of the Phoenicians](http://language.github.com/phoenician) Many writing systems that we use today descended directly from the right-to-left "abjad" (no vowels) created by Phoenicians in 1050 BC. The first letter of the alphabet (alf) represents a glottal stop, as in Dene. * alf ("ox") ** æ [ î]** u10900 * bet ("house") **b [b]** u10901 * gaml ("camel") **g […°]** u10902 * ... ### [It's all ŒµŒªŒªŒ∑ŒΩŒπŒ∫Œ¨ to me!](http://language.github.com/greek) In 800 BC, the Greeks starting writing left-to-right, and each letter had upper and lower "case" . They used the alphabet to represent numbers as well and 3 extra characters were added to the phonetic symbols to complete numeral writing system. * Œë Œ± 1 alpha **[a] [aÀê]**, **[a]** * Œí Œ≤ 2 beta **[b]**, **[v]** * Œì Œ≥ 3 gamma **[…°]**, **[…£]** * œõ 6 digamma * œü 90 koppa * œ° 900 sampi ### [I <3 T√•√Æch√¥!](http://language.github.com/dene) * dotless I * crazy L * high tone, low tone, nasal * schwa * winmac denefont!
